summary: A prince becomes involved in the struggle between a forest princess and the encroachment of mechanization.

reviews.content: Great story, but beware this is a movie thought for adults.
My favourite movie of all time
great. It's just great.

This was a film I accidentally stumbled upon as a young boy on TV, forgot about, and always wondered about later in life. I kept remembering it because it profoundly touched me. Then, one providential day, I learned what it was actually called and revisited it as an adult. I believe it is an absolute masterpiece and I share it with any who are open to watching it.
very good film as always gibli studios do their best, very well done story that holds you.
Fabulous animation, beautiful landscapes and inspiring story.

The Studio Ghibli stuff is just not for me. I think I'm done trying to find appreciation for them at my age. The voice work just seemed too passive and uninvolved. It was like they were bored, or directed to be intentionally cheesy or bland. Where's the emotion, the intensity? 
The story line was kinda thin on development; nebulous at times. The ending didn't do much for me, either. Visually it was largely impressive. The vibrancy of the nature the movie was set it and the outfits is what worked best for me. 2.4 stars
One of the greatest movies of all time, if not the greatest.
absolute mustsee. a serious, mature film that is certainly not intended for or catering to children
Epic movie with ghibli level animation, and a great story and message to deliver.
One of my favorite movies!! It's a must see if you like anime / animations! :D
The more I watch this film, the more I appreciate it. And don't forget to notice the soundtrack.

A true masterpiece. It's ideas are way before it's time!
Great movie. Real sense of action and adventure.

It is the best studio ghibli film because it is not held back by annoying ass main characters. It also has complex characters that are neither good nor bad and I like that. the animation is fantastic as well.
absoloute masterpiese. main "villan" has the best motives ive seen, it has fantastic animations easaly my favurite.

A unique film that should be on everyone's must-see list.
I fell in love with this movie almost immediately. The soundtrack is very beautiful and is as powerful in some parts is it is calm in others. The actors in the English dub were perfect also, Minnie Driver was a perfect choice for Lady Eboshi and Keith David's work as Lord Okkoto is underappreciated in my opinion. The film was very immersive, I was too into the story to notice that more than 2 hours had past.
Overall, this is a perfect movie that sits as my absolute favourite movie of all time.

Princess Mononoke is another major picture from Hayao Miyazaki that stands out due to its intensity and violence shown compared to many other of his films. They make a good point to show that this will not be a family friendly venture right from the very beginning. The violence can sometimes seem a bit outlandish such as shooting an arrow causes someone to be decapitated. This is only a minor nitpick since it doesn't take me out of the film that much. There is a lot going on in the film and if doesn't feeling like any part of it is wasted by simple distractions or one-off jokes or quips. It makes a point to show the brutality of war, but also its ambiguity because of the ability to see the understandable motivations with all the major players in the battles shown. The two main characters reflect the opposing viewpoints regarding war: the need for war and the need for compromise. The Mononoke character is a strong character that's full of heart, but also shows the dangers of someone feeling the need to jump into war. The Ashitaka character is more level-minded, but also shows the dangers and sacrifice that may happen for those fighting for peace and compromise with two opposing and violent factions. From the animation to the message, there is a lot to love about this movie.

Great Movie.
And you can watch it on Netflix with VPN(If you are in Japan, The US, or Canada)
I have loved this movie since the first time I saw it all those years ago. No matter how many times I see it, the magic never fades.
6 years ago- Beautifully animated to the point where one's jaw drops, the movie holds viewer with strong action and character development.
This is an awesome film. Avatar definitely tried to copy the themes of this story but Princess Mononoke will always be beyond superior.
Incredible storytelling and animation.
We’re was the air conditioning

I found it tremendously difficult to connect with this movie on any level. The improvements they made to the animation actually brought the Ghibli style more in line with other anime I've seen, most notably DBZ, and I didn't find the plot to be particularly compelling, especially after the first act when it became a thinly-veiled environmentalism sermon. Hayao's ability to find different ways to highlight the importance of preserving nature is impressive but I was rather exhausted by the end of this lengthy movie.

I'm not really into anime so my review won't be that passionate, but clearly this movie's awesome. The visuals and ideas which were born inside of Mijazaki's head are insanely interesting and nuanced and I loved it very much because we just don't see these kinds of movies these days. I like this movie a lot, it's just I couldn't connect emotionally to the characters, that's why my rating just isn't that high. For sure it's an extremely solid movie with likable characters and beautiful visuals, but I wanted a bit more of the story, I don't know particularly what, but these movies lack something I don't know how to describe. Maybe I just have to adjust to this way of storytelling and just enjoy it more, but you know it isn't that easy and I don't want to overrate something just because it's a classic. So that's that, I finally watched it and I decided to watch some more arty films so yeah. If you read this, please comment something to this review, I'm interested.

Decided to discover Miyazaki for the first time without having seen any of his films before and finally got around to serious work. Not that they were not serious before, but there really is much more depth and meaning than in his previous films.

The beginning was especially shocking. I thought it was going to be another kids cartoon, and there are decaying skeletons, pools of blood, demons, dismemberment and decapitation only in the first 15 minutes! And then in general places almost horror. I didn't expect this Miyazaki...

But when I got used to the level of cruelty and maturity of this film, I also saw its philosophy, symbolism, problematics. "Princess Mononoke" seems to have absorbed the best of the master's previous works: the idea of ​​​​a conflict between people and nature, touched upon back in Nausicaa, is shown here much more thoroughly, the spirit of the forest, which Totoro was, is here a truly mythical creature, and the princess herself seems to be collective the image of all the previous heroines of Miyazaki - everything came together here. The visuals are great as well as the music.

I can find fault with the implausibility of an ordinary bow arrow being capable of blowing heads off like a cannon ball, or chopping off limbs like an axe, with a single hit. I understand that this is a magical fantasy, but the arrows are not magical. Sometimes there was a feeling that Hayao just wanted more blood in order to go far beyond the scope of children's films.

And the rest I'm impressed. So far, this is Miyazaki's biggest, most beautiful and grown-up film. However, the next film in line is Spirited Away, which now intrigues me even more.

one of the best anime movies i have had the pleasure of watching 
clare danes and billy bob give this a good vibe

Goosebumps! The contrast of the sound and the visuals mix to create what can only be described as perfection. This film is my number 1 suggestion for must watch films. It has love, gods, war, incredible characters and best of all other than the studio Ghibli touch it has a phenomenal and deeply educated narrative that beautifully depicts the directors thoughts and values and modern society. My all time favourite film and I think it will be impossible to de throne it.
The movie is beautifully animated, the characters are well-written and the whole movie feels like an amazing walkthrough of a magnificent forest.
I just don't understand the appeal of anime.
Special Effects: 1,0/Sound Effects: 1,0/Acting: 1,0/Story: 1,5

Watched this for the first time in about 10 years recently. For some reason I always remembered it being much less rich visually. It's still amongst my least favourite of the Ghiblis I've seen (it somehow lackssome of the magic of others for me, though I know I'm v much on my own here) but of course that's great company to be in.
Incredibly charming and always engaging. Truly a classic of the genre. I've no idea what took me so long but I'm glad I got round to watching it.

The first true Ghibli fantasy epic since „Laputa" is its darkest movie yet (I am watching all Ghibli movies in the order they were released so pardon my anachronism here), except of course "Grave of the Fireflies". Because of some quite pronounced brutality (visible blood in large amounts, decapitations even) it seemed more like an old folk saga than modern fantasy story, giving it a overall vibe of venerability. And while the ecological themes so prevalent in nearly all Ghibli fantasy productions here are also obvious, the plot itself is far removed from being so. It doesn't have any clear fairy-tale-like structure and resembles in some aspects modern political dramas, albeit subtlety. There is surprise here, to be sure, there are also emotions, and it all seems somewhat grandiose in the end. Maybe not profound (old lessons repeated over and over again quickly loose their profoundness),  but yes, certainly grandiose. In the end "Princess Mononoke" is rather unlike anything that Ghibli has done before, but only as long as you fail to remember that even before they were named that, they made "Nausicaä". Rhythms from the Valley of the Wind echo in wolf princess' ears.

Princess Mononoke is one of the best animated movies I have seen in a long time, and is up there with Studio Ghibli's best along with Spirited Away. I will say I am probably biased, as I am a huge Studio Ghibli fan, and love all of their films, I even like Cat Returns, which along with PomPoko is considered as one of the weaker Ghibli efforts. The animation in Princess Mononoke is absolutely stunning, with rich detailed backgrounds and brilliant character animation. The image of the Stag actually made my jaw drop. The music is fantastic as well, and although environmentalism is a subject matter very difficult to get right, what the filmmakers succeeded in doing was making a highly intriguing story that was not only original but succeeded in not being preachy at all. The film is also helped by the high calibre vocal talents of Minnie Driver, Claire Danes, Billy Bob Thornton et al (voicing quite remarkable characters) and a strong script. True, some of the images like the Demon Worm, may frighten younger viewers, but it is fair to say they were very powerful. All in all, Princess Mononoke is breathtaking and I recommend it highly. 10/10 Bethany Cox

This film is fabulous! I can't believe I put off seeing this movie until now. This movie has very quickly become one of my top favorite movies of all time! Everything from the animation to the music and story are beautiful. I fell in love with theses with these characters, they felt so real to me, I have not seen such masterful animated characterization since Avatar The Last Airbender, they truly do feel alive. Also I simply must give amazing credit to the overall tone and maturity of this story, yes, this movie can be brutal at times and never shy's away from showing everything from death to blood and dismemberment, it's very rare that a movie targeted at kids, (yes I know it's rated PG-13 but this movie to me can still be targeted at kids) won't hold back so as not to scare or intimidate, and boy does this really help pull you in and invest you even more, and I appreciate that. The only negative thing I can really say is that it felt to me as though the ending came somewhat abruptly and it felt rushed to me, leaving characters and some plotlines unresolved in my opinion. Not a bad ending by any means just somewhat unsatisfying. Overall this movie is great and I highly recommend this film to any lover of animation or great story telling in general, do yourself a favor anf pick up a copy! I give Princess Mononoke a 9/10.

Typical of Studio Ghibli movies, Princess Mononoke has a more comprehensive plot than your usual Good v. Evil story. This could've easily devolved into Nature = Good, Humans = Bad (which is actually what I was expecting) but to my pleasant surprise, it wasn't that at all. We have the personification of man v. nature, the latter including spirits and other creatures from Japanese and Chinese folklore. I'm still not entirely sure what the human's motivation was, but I'll just assume it was good ol' fashioned need for resources. The violence of the movie was jarring (+$1) at first, but intriguing after the shock wore off. There's some really beautiful imagery here, as one is to expect from a Ghibli movie concerning nature. I especially enjoyed the putrefying look of Okkoto (Keith David), the elderly, white boar god. I also loved how they animated San (Claire Danes) in battle as a ninja who defies the laws of physics. I think if you had knowledge of Japanese folklore you'd appreciate this movie more (here's a good vid), but it's still a must-see for anime fans, especially those who enjoy animation with more substance and nuance.

For the most part, Princess Mononoke maintains the magnificent world construction while keeping the narrative and conflicts grounded. The plot begins slowly in order to humanize the experience and help the audience to come to know each character in the film, whether big or minor. And, despite the big action moments, you still get to follow each character and care about them. It also has an environmental message that is effectively communicated. It may not have been the most emotional Ghibli film, but it was the most grandiose Ghibli film yet.
It might be beautifully drawn, but even the environmental message gets lost due to total inconsistency of the protagonist
Amazing, incredible, show-stopping
Fantastic movie! Definitely at the top of my list!
Not into anime, other than Akira, but this was a great movie if you are patient
Princess Mononoke is the Japanese Lord of the Rings?
Human destruction in order to develop a better life by eliminating their environment
Stunning animation and a wonderful story. Feels less like a movie and more like a visual fable. A perfect anime film!

An enjoyable, though, with all Miyazaki films, surprisingly dense, movie that rightfully questions human nature and modern society without altogether condemning it. It's respectful of differing opinions, which, for some, may lead to a disappointing conclusion, with neither side fully defeated, but rightfully capturing the complexities of society and the nature we coexist with.
The kind of wonderful animation and creative storytelling that we've come to expect from the masters at Studio Ghibli!

Typical great animation and visual design. It's a fun and scary adventure rolled into one with, at times, some dark moments. The giant animals are awesome and the creatures of the forest are cool. The Forest Spirit itself is so strange and creepy, but really well done.
One of the best anime films ever made, bar none.
The ecological message of Miyazaki is so rich and full of power that the movie is understood beyond it. 10/10
Beautiful and meaningful - the best anime film of all time!
Really watchable without any waste but fails to hit the highs
This film is okay, but nothing more. Watching the movie is more or less interesting, but there is absolutely no immersion and atmosphere, just one beautiful picture is replaced by another
This is an exceptional film. I loved it and it is great for kids too. I recommend it 100%.
I don't get what the other reviewers liked about this. Uninteresting story with very little plot. Preachy and extremely slow paced with no pay-off in the end. Easily forgettable movie.

A soulless Nausicaä.
A world filled with indifferent and psychopathic creatures. The deer is the only creature with a heart.

This classic created by the famous Hayao Miyazaki, compared to the lighter 'My Neighbor Totoro' or even 'Spirited Away', is brutal and uncompromising. Miyazaki was ahead of the time in expressing environmental awareness and in depiction of the destruction of nature done by her greatest enemy – mankind. Salvation comes in the image of Prince Ashitaki, who has become a target of damnation, and gets help from princess raised by wolves... For me, this goes in the masterpiece file. It is necessary to watch it with great attention in order to grasp all the nuances and details of the story. And finally, here are two quotes that sound terrifying current: "These days, there are angry ghosts all around us. Dead from wars, sickness, starvation, and nobody cares. So - you say you're under a curse. So what, so's the whole damn world." "Life is suffering. It's hard. The world is cursed. But still you find reasons to keep living."

This film is an anime classic. It has a great story, a bit of romance, stunning visuals and animation, and an interesting amount of surprisingly gory violence. It feels like a film more directed towards mature audiences, which is refreshing and fives it a nice visceral feel. Thoroughly enjoyable to watch for older teens or adults.

Another epic Hayao Miyazaki masterpiece. It's a 1997 movie and it has the most beautiful animation I've ever seen. Mononoke and Ashitaka are the most complex characters written by Hayao (specially Ashitaka), and the war between humans and gods of the forest is just the beginning. An antelope has more character development than at least 75% of Disney supporting characters. This movie works in absolutely everything: action, drama, "romance", war, fantasy, and the feeling of urgency. Oh, and it could have the R rating, if it wasn't an animated movie.
Absolutely Epic. A must-watch for every adult.

Regarded as Hayao Miyazaki's best, this epic with meaningful themes tells a profoundly rich tale with which we should all be able to identify.
And then it has Billy Bob Thornton. Go figure.

Princess Monoke is a film by Studio Gihibili with an incredible and powerful story filled with mature themes, violence, adventure, and mythology. It tells the story of of a young man who sets out on a journey to cure himself from a lethal curse and is embroiled in an epic conflict between giant wolves, pigs, and other forest creatures against the humans who are reaping the forest for its resources. This film features political and environmentalist messages but it does not bog down the story but enhances it with great characters and lots of great but quite violent action. Not a movie for kids but it entertains with its unique lore. It's well put together and a quite beautiful film.

The first time I watched this movie I was on a Studio Ghibli marathon, and let me tell you, not only in my opinion is it the best Studio Ghibli movie, but Princess Mononoke for me, was just about as close to perfect as you can get! The last hour of the movie is inspiring, terrifying, and absolutely timeless. If you consider yourself a film buff or fan of anime in general, then Princess Mononoke is a quintessential piece!

Don't mess with nature. Wow this movie really reflected the fame it got. In addition to the longest run-time compared to the previous Ghibli movies, the animation was also much more impressive and breathtaking. I was hooked from the opening, which showed an intense chase and fight scene. The story was intricate and made me want to see how it would all unveil. Unexpectedly, there were a lot of gore, which made the action even more thrilling. The theme about man versus nature and how nature can strike back were adamantly clear and impactful not only in 1997, but also now. For me, this is the best movie from Miyazaki so far and it was a phenomenal experience. 9.5/10
The most inspired and inspiring movie ever made; the mechanisms of its narrative are similar to ancient mythology than to modern dramatic/action movies.

Although I don't like the darker type of contrast used in this movie, I have to admit that it has a pleasing story and the metaphor used for nature in the characters of the princess and other characters is incredible!
This movie is a very very awesome looking anime, but it is also not done to death story
Really good movie, I highly suggest it.

Out of all the Studio Ghibli films I've seen in my life, this one definitely has the best animation. However, I can't go so far as to declare it a masterpiece, when there are some definite problems involving the titular Princess Mononoke character and some of the ideas that I felt it could've presented a lot better.

It's...okay. The animation is pretty enough, and the creatures they do show are passable, but it lacks inspiration and charm. Maybe my view on it will change in the future, but for now, it's no more than a sub par animated movie

Sympathy for the Earth from Miyazaki.

Hayao Miyazaki's environmental epic anime Princess Mononoke (1997) is a behemoth of a feature with glorious hand drawn animation from Studio Ghibli and sincere feeling from Miyazaki's thoughtful script. Princess Mononoke is another fantasy adventure anime, much like his earlier films, but I've always felt that Princess Mononoke is Miyazaki's fully realized vision for his debut movie Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind. The similar themes, imagery, and story are obvious.

Similarly, Princess Mononoke is really upheld by Miyazaki's stunning direction and brave environmentalist narrative alongside Ghibli's breathtaking animation. The lush green forestry, oozing bloody gore, piercing eye drawings, and fluid running movements are all peak animation for Ghibli. Princess Mononoke is a revelation of visionary direction with a genuine peaceful message delivered by Hayao Miyazaki's authentic writing voice. It's easily one of his best pictures.

Miyazaki's direction sweeps you away on a fantasy odyssey to save a forest from humanity's greed, capitalism, and warmongering. Violence is never the answer in Miyazaki's movies and I appreciate his peaceful themes, serene atmosphere, and heartfelt filmmaking for Princess Mononoke. Miyazaki's writing is creative, especially for the forest spirit encounters and the relationship between Princess Mononoke and the young hero prince she comes to love and understand. Hayao Miyazaki and Takeshi Seyama's editing is so smooth and naturally flowing that Princess Mononoke feels half its tremendous 134 minute length.

Claire Danes is fearsome and empathetic as Princess Mononoke the Wolfchild. She's confident and intense as this warrior for the woods, yet her softer voice fits Mononoke's emotional personality, full of heart and love for the forest and its animals. Danes does a phenomenal job voicing Hayao Miyazaki's iconic vanguard of the trees: Princess San Mononoke. Likewise, Billy Crudup is excellent as the young hero Prince Ashitaka. His heroism is not marked by his skillful archery or powerful sword strikes, but rather his unwavering loyalty to nature and goodness. Crudup's sensitive voice gently captures Prince Ashitaka's love for Princess Mononoke as well as his boundless quest for peace.

Gillian Anderson's dark charisma and deep intensity are perfect for Moro the Wolf. Billy Bob Thornton is surprisingly funny and entertaining as the quirky, self-serving villain Jigo the Monk. Minnie Driver's posh English accent really works for the selfish female ruler Lady Eboshi. She's welcoming and commanding as a leader, but also conniving as she plots to take over the world by smiting a forest god. Jada Pinkett Smith is funny as the former brothel lady and current ironworker Toki with her persistent attitude and personality. Honestly, the new English Dub cast makes Princess Mononoke worth hearing in English for me as this all star cast voices Miyazaki's art with fervent reverence for the picture.

Atsushi Okui's cinematography is particularly striking and resolute with still wide shots of the trees and the spirit of the woods for a heavenly feel. His face close-ups are wonderfully emotional and his far wide shots of forests and lakes are really beautiful. Joe Hisaishi's score swells with symphonic sympathy for the creatures with gentle orchestral passages. His phrasing is simply divine with really memorable music for Princess Mononoke. Hisaishi's scores are one of the magical elements of Hayao Miyazaki's anime features.

Michihiro Itou and Nobutaka Hirooka's sound design for Princess Mononoke is really noticeable. Their quiet and loud dynamics are quite special as all the sound cuts out wherever the spirit of the forest appears. This sudden stillness makes the woods feel truly tranquil with an earnest love of nature on display. You hear cicadas at night, flowing water, wind rustling falling leaves or fields of grass. Everything in Princess Mononoke is natural.

Masashi Ando, Yoshifumi Kondou, and Kitarou Kousaka's visual effects for Princess Mononoke are resplendent with magical glowing for the spirit of the forest's nightwalker form or the celestial glow for the smaller of the wood spirits. I love all the gushing blood as Princess Mononoke remains Miyazaki's most gory and shocking film. These artists allow audiences to realize how horrific bloody violence is when faced with bleeding animals of massive size and soul. There is a real feeling put into this picture. 

Furthermore, Yōji Takeshige. Naoya Tanaka. Kazuo Oga. Satoshi Kuroda, and Nizou Yamamoto's art direction is lovely with pretty designs for an abundantly alive forest and starkly industrial ironworks village in juxtaposition to the woods' natural beauty. Their aesthetics are interesting and whoever designed Princess Mononoke herself did a wonderful job making her look unique, cool, and lovely. I'd say that Princess Mononoke has a unique look for everyone in it.

In conclusion, Princess Mononoke is a fierce statement in favor of defending Earth's natural beauty and wildlife.
This is how a male protagonist should be.
Not my favorite Ghibli film, I feel like this movie is best understood the second time around. The characters are great, and I enjoyed the movie.
Brilliance animated.
Ghibli and Miyazaki creating a benchmark for the entire genre.

Although 'Princess Mononoke(1997)' is replete with breathtaking visuals, prodigious imagination and rich content yet the story-telling lacks clarity.

Many questions need to answer whys and whats until you start taking it (the plot) at its face value.

Princess Mononoke is perhaps the 'weirdest' Miyazaki movie. There's so much mythology and japanese culture. I actually didn't at first like it that much. But now I think it's one of Miyazaki's best. It's a bit hard to understand at first, but it's worth your time.

I just don't get anime movies. I watch them, I understand their worlds but man they're so boring. This is a rated r animated anime movie. Some animated movies that are rated r push the boundaries. This movie did not. I was bored and I don't care for the characters. I hope spirited away is better.

내 최고의 인생 영화 1위다.
자연과 동물, 인간의 조화를 주장하는 영화.
인간에 의해 파괴되는 자연과 동물이 얼마나 불쌍한지, 동물을 왜 보호해야하는지 다시한번 일깨워주는 영화다.
It is the number one movie in my life.
A film that claims the harmony between nature, animals, and humans.
This film reminds us of how poor nature and animals are destroyed by humans and why we need to protect them.

At this point, this is just what I've come to expect from Miyazaki. It has fun characters and great visuals. This was one of the bigger adventures and I really liked that. I'd probably rank it as my second favorite film of his so far.

Far more directly brutal than the prototypical Ghibli fim as defined by previous releases (even Grave of the Fireflies left most of its violence abstract), but just as creative and perhaps even more powerful. Abandoning much of the family dynamic and childhood themes that were so prevalent previously, Princess Mononoke feels mature right out of the gate and doesn't stop, exploring complex (not necessarily evil) characters in competition for what resources they each require, though the ending does feel too neat given the brutality of the conflict. The environmentalist themes, role of the titular character, and even the design of the Deer God are eerily reminiscent of Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind, feeling like something of a soft remake to me; somewhat more restricted in terms of pure creativity, though far more intellient in its comments on human nature, survival, and change. I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the quality of the animation, including some fantastic action sequences and beautiful natural backdrops. Though Mononoke is often considered among the great films of the venerable studio and is doubtlessly solid, I personally consider it to be more of a middling effort overall when compared to some of their other masterpieces. (4/5)

I'm convinced this is the film Studio Ghibli spent its early years building up to. While previous efforts like Castle in the Sky and My Neighbor Totoro contained mythical elements - sleepy deities, spritely spirits, magic-tinged talents - the influence of god-level beings often feels secondary, relegated to a few enchanting (yet fleeting) glimpses. In Princess Mononoke, such divine creatures are essential, active participants. They speak, argue, swing their weight around. We aren't left to guess about their opinions or motivations, because their words and actions carry such a resonant influence. It's mesmerizingly effective, a contrast between the seemingly petty concerns of human tribes and the mass and muscle of a much heavier entity.

Mononoke represents a huge step up for the studio, particularly in that sense of scale. Rather than maintaining the quaint, intimate essence that typified their early output, this time Ghibli has gone sweeping and epic. Everything, from the ambitious, enveloping symphonic score to the wide, gorgeous landscapes and distinct environs, emphasizes this point. We've left the village to find there's a broad undiscovered world out there. Yet the distinguishing little touches and unspoken human gestures haven't been lost in the transition, either. It still looks and feels like a Miyazaki movie, calmingly earnest and heartstrong, but the canvas is larger and more potentially powerful. And man, do they make the most of that promise.

one of my favorite animated movie of all time it's soo good the English dub is umm not good it's trash teehee uwu watch it in the original sub it's better the animation is some of the best I've ever seen I just love this movie it's beautiful uwu. watch it in Japanese it's better
Incredibly good. The work of a genius.

"Life is suffering. It is hard. The world is cursed. But still, you find reasons to keep living."

It had been a while that I've wanted to watch this movie and kept postponing it. My mistake, I should have seen it a long time ago.

It's a beautiful 2D Japanese animation. The story, I didn't have the time to search about, looks like a legend or an old tale. A tale about how hatred and greed can transform good things in devilish full of hate ones. Such a tense and strong tale about gods of the forest and human greed.

I keep repeating, "The best movie I've ever seen."  From the soundtrack to the visuals this movie truly is a must-see. A perfect, and seemingly timeless, mirror of society and greed. Another masterpiece from the legendary Hayao Miyazaki.

To me this is easily the best Miyazaki film. It's still boring and far too simple but at least the story is fairly coherent. Sure in the current environmentalist movement is could become a big hit again.
Classic animated movie. Incredible visuals.

This movie just like many other studio Ghibli's is a classic. The story not only takes you for a joyride but the visuals make me want to jump onto my screen in hope I could be there! I'd recommend this movie to anyone looking for art and a beautiful story.
With its epic scale, exciting story, breathtaking visuals, and ecologist and nature friendly times, it's a landmark in modern animation.
Dope film really good I enjoy it animated well done

Miyazaki's more mature, and relatively recent, fable talks about war and our impact on the environment is still his best. There are some English voice performance issues, but the passion and unbridled anger behind this film gives it the emotional impact it needs. The fantastic animation and attentions to detail remain a Ghibli staple, and the thematic heart is still there. It's violent, and bloody, but it's all part of the message we see through Ashitaka's eyes. A great undertaking, Mononoke remains my favorite and most impactful Ghibli film.

I just don’t get anime movies. I watch them, I understand their worlds but man they’re so boring. This is a rated r animated anime movie. Some animated movies that are rated r push the boundaries. This movie did not. I was bored and I don’t care for the characters. I hope spirited away is better.

Fantastic movie! Darker story telling compared to other Miyazaki works and I think it is better for it. It is a little heavy handed in its moral motifs but not so much as to distract from the storytelling.
Gotta say, these classic animes really “WOW!” us. I love the colors and Ghibli’s animation style.
Princess Monoke is beautifully animated. The storyline and script is quite random but that makes it different and enjoyable.

2 decades and still... hits the nail right on the head. Most of these concepted shots often focus on details in the movie to convey its message - important aspects of behavioral criticism are told through an amazing storyline! Big Name in animated-film history we should keep in mind, such as environmental themes.
Amazing. The music, the animation, the history, is perfect. A magical piece of art
A bit overhyped but still good.

This movie gets Way too much hype, but it is still a great movie. It is fast-paced, with big battles, but it just makes No sense, like, At All. It has No logic, and is just Pure fantasy. If you like movies where you are just enveloped in jargon and nothing has any bearing on logic or physics at all, then you will Love this movie. Nothing is explained, everything just is, and there is no reason for it other than "yep, that's how it is." I don't lie these types of movies, and you either love it or don't like it, but you definitely don't Hate it At All. It is a crazy ride, even though it is pure nonsense. 
Animation is good, but you also have to deal with ancient-animal spirits that are stupid as hell, they don't know anything yet act like they know everything, and people that do nothing right just for self interest. It is as political as it gets, where people destroy everything and animals don't... even though they Do, so it is meaningless. 
I think people just got carried away with the idea that there are giant wolves, because fanatically emotional people seem to Love talking giant wolves. I just don't get the hype at all. It is pure idiocy most of the times, and amazing visuals don't make up for stupid story, dialogue, plot, and Everything else dealing with Sense. I think people that Love Marvel movies like Avengers and Infinity Wars will Love and Adore this movie, because it is all about the Kapow and not about the "why is any of this relevant?"

Listen, I get it if you think this movie is deserving of 5 stars. I would've given it that too if it wasn't for these three reasons. 1. Dialogue: this one is probably the smallest problem out of the three. It's pretty much just a knit pick but I had to say something about it. The problem doesn't arise too often but sometimes the main character could be saying something totally unneeded in the conversation or a side character could say something that was so cheesy I couldn't believe it was in a Miyazaki film. Mind-boggling almost. 2. The Pacing: this is a 2 hour and 13 min movie. Too long for an animated feature film. It kept it up well for the most part but it definitely had some bumps in the road. I was extremely intrigued for the first 45 minutes or however long it was until they got into Iron Town. But as soon as they opened that gate, the story came to a complete hault. The pacing became slow, the conversations started to become exposition heavy and it was just overall boring. It picked back up when Princess Mononoke invaded the town and didn't slow back down until about an hour left in the movie but that one wasn't as long. 3. Confusion: the story itself is great, don't get me wrong. Sure, it gets heavy handed at times with its preachiness but not enough to make you role your eyes and cut off the TV. The confusion stems from too much stuff going on and not enough time to explain. I guess you could say there was not enough exposition or at least, not where it was needed. Like I didn't even know until the end of the movie that the bore at the beginning was a god. Heck, I didn't even know until the credits rolled why he turned into demon. But again, the issues I had with movie didn't take away from my experience. I still loved it and would love to explore more of this world. And gee wiz, was the animation amazing. Over 2 decades and that is still one of the most beautiful animated movies I've seen. Absolutely astonishing.
That's my favorite Studio Ghibli movie ♡

A thing of beauty with a lot of meaning, even if that meaning is very easy to spot and not very subtle. A must if you like the genre, and still a good movie if you don't. Unfortunately I am in the latter category, but that is just me.
Rewatching then all again since they are now available on netflix. Studio ghibli is simple put, the pinnacle in beautiful animated storytelling.

It's full of imagination and fantastic imagery; and the animation is outstanding. It's an important film too; being the inspiration for numerous works since (including The Last Airbender cartoon series and James Cameron's Avatar film). The story and characters are rich, and it gives an important message about humans abuse of nature.
Probably just me then that felt this movie is overrated. Sorry waste of my time.
A masterpiece from Studio Ghibli, Princess Mononoke creates a wonderful universe filled with intriguing characters and an epic adventure.

Beautiful and unique in its own way. Miyazaki does it again.

4/5.
This is the best movie I have ever seen.. I am left with no words
Among the most impressive movies I have ever seen. Truly amazing.

Princess Mononoke is a film comparable to only a handful of others; it leaves an remarkable sense of awe that seldom appears in entertainment. Though stiff, the animation is incredibly true to life. Every motion is porous with intent. Character all exist with depth. If you want a film that sticks in your head for days after a viewing, Mononoke is the first place to look.
One of my favorite movies ever. The art is spectacular, and the story is worthy of it.

Explores the relationship between nature and modernity in a way which western movies with their simplistic dichotomies never do. 

It's not this film's beauty but it's intelligence which make it a classic.
Great movie. Astonishing most of the way through, but it gets a little preachy in many parts. If the message was less on-the-nose it would easily be a 5 star film.
A beautifully animated movie with a captivating storyline and strongly written characters. A must-see.

First Studio Ghibli movie to mix hand-drawn and CG-animation, resulting in a piece of art and the greatest Studio Ghibli film ever created. A masterwork with compelling characters, a fascinating story and a great message to be learned. Hayao Miyazaki's best film still manages to put many modern anime movies to shame with its amazing visuals, action packed scenes and wonderful soundtrack by Joe Hisaishi.
Mononoke Hime avoids the classic black or white morality issue and deals with more powerful themes than other Ghibli movies, turning this film from something that could've easily been a children's book into a fantastic tale for people of all ages. This is, in my opinion, the best anime film of all time.
Hand drawn images will haunt your dreams both good/bad. Story is original and your well invested in characters after first few scenes. Absolutely beautiful film, not recommended for small kids 12+
Beautiful drawing and incredible voice acting to go along with it, all I can say about this are that it is a one of a kind.
The story struggles to keep up its pace and has some narrative misteps along the way, also can't help feel preachy at times. But the overall themes and maturity of the film are remarkable.
